Nice video, only one remark, if you find it interesting ;) 15:31 In a free body diagram, the direction in which you draw an arrow defines the direction of that force. So actually the minus sign doesn't belong there, because the arrow already points in the negative direction (assuming the coordinate system is defined as usual) It would be different if the force was written as a vector, because then the arrow is only an indication that there is a force with some direction.

@Physics Girl You didn't really talk much about the collision aspect of friction, you only briefly mention it at the beginning. It may not always be the biggest aspect of friction, but surely it plays a role. I mean if you were to take a sideways step/row of triangle bumps/ridges and push them along another row of triangle ridges along the bottom, the top ridges would always be falling into the spaces in the bottom and then if you push them along, would climb back out. This would be a friction. If you rapidly moved one over the other there would be lots of collisions and instances with one climbing over the other slowing down the movement. It would also take a steeper incline before one fell off the other depending on the size of the triangles and other factors. Surely this applies on smaller scale as well.

Like if we are talking about shoes, or car tires, they have ridges. These ridges on the flexible material with weight flatten out but want to go back to the standard shape. So you have the additional friction of pushing against this material rebound factor. This is why more flexible and uneven materials provide more friction under weight. Matter collusion friction becomes a big factor sometimes when we are trying to create friction. Is there a physics formula that could possibly fully calculate that factor with the rest?
On the more extreme end, you have things like cleats, which are shoes with spikes and snow tires, which are either car tires with something like chains on them or on bicycle tires are small metal spikes along the ridge of the wheel, using material collision to it's fullest to increase friction. And surely these count as "friction", or at least need to be considered in the same formulas when calculating friction. Like if the cars tires are "bald" AKA all the ridges have been worn away from repeated collisions making the tires relatively smooth, the car would take much longer to stop. And if there was a series of speed bumps, it would stop sooner.

Also, as you talk about molecular attraction (which I kind of already knew but your lesson helped focus in my mind in regards to friction) Might you call water tension, a form of "friction"? I mean water tension is how things can be wet without having to sit right on top of whatever surface, without water tension things would dry immediately with the smallest amount of gravitational force.(watched a video recently about a material called "dry water" [I think that was the name] that does nearly just that because of it's lack of surface tension) And without water tension, water could not bead up. (which I'm sure you already know all this) Water tension can also do things like make something wet cling to a vertical wall if the item isn't too heavy and the surface area is great enough. So is water tension just a specialized term for water friction? Or is there a difference?

Static friction is not exactly equal to µₛFₙ. Maximum static friction is. Actual static friction is only ever as high as it needs to be to stop the object from moving. Otherwise friction would cause the object to move and that's just weird.

I am involved with practical measurement of friction in a technical environment. An important thing to remember is what you mentioned at one point: Friction is messy. mu is nowhere near the constant for which it is introduced in high school physics.
A famous quote of our lab engineers when you order measurement of a coefficient of friction: "What value do you want?"
It depends on lubrication, on aging of involved materials like rubber or oxydation of metal surfaces, on ambient conditions like temperature, humidity, vibration, on speed, on pressure (even if the straight up Coulomb theory say it doesn't).
So one thing to absorb: Yes, you can calculate with the law of Coulomb. But there are significant error bars on those results.

Careful... the force of static friction doesn't equal (u_s)(F_N) in all cases. That is the maximum possible force of static friction. In general, F_s <= (u_s)(F_N), with the equality only true if something in the situation let's you know you are accessing the maximum static friction force.

Also, technically, the surfaces in static friction are not moving *with respect to each other*. They could be moving overall (such as the static friction between an unattached tool box and the bed in the back of a truck).

Hello Dianna,
I saw something that might be usefull as a physics riddle.
Take an inclined plane and two cylinders with different radii.
Which cylinder will reach the bottom first?
Turns out that the both reach the bottom at the same time.
So the speed of a rolling cylinder on in inclined plane is independent
of the raduis of the cylinder.
If on cylinder is hollow and the other is full, there will be
difference is speed. This was very counterintuitive for me.

Nice video, as always. Just want to point out that at 10:20, the formula given is for maximum static friction, not static friction in general. Static friction can be as small as 0 when there is no tendency of relative motion between 2 contacting surfaces, and it can be as large as the product of static friction coefficient and the normal force when the relative motion between the surfaces is about to start. Imagine a book resting on a table. When there is no horizontal force on the book, the static friction is actually 0. When there is a horizontal force applied yet the book remains stationary on the table, then the static friction must be equal to the applied force but in opposite direction so the net force on the book is zero. But if the applied force keeps increasing, eventually the book slides on the table because the force exceeds the value of maximum static friction and the static friction on the book can’t increase beyond that.

There is the static and the dynamic friction forces which don't depend on the area, but there is also adhesion (caused by van der Waals forces) which is proportional to the contact area. With just friction an ant couldn't climb up a wall without anybody pushing against it like you did the book and a Formula 1 car wouldn't need wide tires to go really fast around a curve.

I am sorta confused about your explanation on why friction exists... 3:14
You know even the materials that mutually repel each other shows friction... like water droplets on hydrophobic substances.
So, to claim that friction exist due to attraction between molecules is kind of flawed.
In most general case, it is just the balancing act of normal force that locks the microbumps between surfaces; and this normal force is enough to create friction. However, the amount of intermolecular force between surface WILL/CAN define the coefficient of frictions.

I think ice and banana peel acts different than normal friction .

Because when we keep a wooden block on a wooden silde , it's too tough to slide it down ,since rough wood has a higher friction .
But if we keep a smooth glass block , it would slide down like butter ...

But in case of ice and banana , i think it is not because of low friction but because of shedding of material ...
Let me make myself clear ...
See . When you were sliding down the grassy slope on an ice block , the layer of ice in contact with the grass was continuously shedding and melting , leaving behind a residue of water , and the rest of the ice goes forward and on and on and on , until the ice totally melts and you stop sliding anymore ... Same with a banana peel . The banana peel leaves behind a jelly residue and slides forward ...
But in case of glass , it is simply a matter of low friction ... There is no question of residue left behind , acting like a lubricant ...

So ice and banana peel act like a solid with a residue that acts like a lubricant. ... The same happens with graphite ... Because graphite also leaves behind the layer of contact and moves on with the new layer of contact and on and on ... If Graphite and ice did not have such a tendency , they would have a huge friction ...

Try sliding dry ice and normal ice .

Hey Diana... absolutely love your physics class vids and all your other content. But please don’t use the roughness analogy for friction. It’s the amount of surface area in contact with the other surface that maximises the molecular forces that lead to friction, not the surface roughness. Slick tyres on motor racing cars and motorcycles are the classic example here.  If you want to demonstrate the power of friction, a MotoGP rider’s motorcycle tyre has a contact patch with the ground of around the size of a credit card which is amazing considering the cornering speeds... perhaps a video on that might be interesting? 😉

There are two kinds of friction: the electromagnetic "stickiness", and just the shape alone. In a universe without electromagnetic "stickiness", they would still have friction in our size range. Friction would be a lot less common, and would depend heavily on how smooth a surface is, and what it's made from. They would have a large capacity to select how much friction they want; we are the ones who are mostly forced to deal with having lots of it.
Just remember, friction is a force that rubs you the 'wrong way' , meaning that friction opposes the motion of a body.

That car drifting wasn't locking up the wheels. It's actually the opposite. The wheels are over-rotating and breaking the friction between the tires and the pavement in order to slide along the surface. But it looked cool.

Interesting example of a car, the coefficient of certain materials can change under load, rubber - of which the tires are made - for example. So when the car brakes hard, the energy is shifted to the front tires, increasing the load and thus the Coefficient.

If friction is the surface phenomenon, then why its independent of surface area? Please Explain

Nice video. However, there is a misconception at 10:18. Static friction (non slip friction) is NOT equal to mu_s F_N. That value is the maximum non slip friction can be before it starts to slide. The value of the non slip friction is deduced from Newton 2nd law. In the example of the book that does not fall off the wall, the static friction is opposite to the book weight mg, no matter what the value of F_N is. If you don't push hard enough such that mu_s F_N falls below mg then the book will slide.
